thread.title: Fly 17 hours from Dubai to Panama City? Now you can, in a Boeing 777 200LR
thread.title_full: Fly 17 hours from Dubai to Panama City? Now you can, in a Boeing 777 200LR

author: Steve Wilhelm
title: Fly 17 hours from Dubai to Panama City? Now you can, in a Boeing 777 200LR
text:
Fly 17 hours from Dubai to Panama City? Now you can, in a Boeing 777 200LR Aug 13, 2015, 1:45pm PDT Industries & Tags Steve Wilhelm Staff Writer Puget Sound Business Journal Steve Wilhelm Staff Writer Puget Sound Business Journal Home of the Day Enlarge Emirates The 777 200LR gets its range by shedding 33 feet of length, and thus weight, compared to… more Boeing’s longest-range plane, the 777 200LR, will stretch its wings further in February, when it starts flying for 17 hours 35 minutes nonstop, from Panama City to Dubai, for Emirates Airlines. That’s a long time in one Boeing (NYSE: BA) seat. The new route will trump long-distance routes operated by Australia’s Qantas , which usually are the longest route. The Boeing aircraft is currently the longest-range aircraft in the world, with a range of 8,555 nautical miles according to Boeing’s website. This distance capability will be superseded by Boeing’s 777-8X jet, which is rated at 8,700 nautical miles. Emirates configures the two-engine wide-body 777 200LR (Long range) for 266 seats. The 200LR is powered for distance, using the same 115,000-pound thrust engines as the larger 777 300, but pushing 33 feet less fuselage length. The new route will connect Emirates’ hub in Dubai with Panama City as a hub for Central America. A Bloomberg story estimated the distance at 8,590 miles . “Panama City will be our first destination gateway in Central America, providing a convenient option for our passengers traveling from or through our global hub in Dubai and onward to destinations throughout Central America, the Caribbean and the northern part of South America,” said His Highness Sheikh Ahmed bin Saeed Al Maktoum , chairman and chief executive of Emirates Airline & Group, in a statement. Emirates operates the largest 777 fleet in the world, and will be accepting is 150th of the Everett-built model in coming months.
